dialogue: Well, the first thing is to find you a room. Where’s your luggage?
I don’t have any.
None?
I thought it best to go to the airport empty-handed, to disguise my intentions.
Ray? O’Malley pops his head in.
His Eminence will require toiletries, some clean clothes, and choir dress of course. Monsignor O’Malley will look after you.
I thought for a moment I was imagining them... Where I come from, they are considered very special animals. They symbolise healing and transformation.
Well, here they keep escaping and being run over. We should go back - the evening curfew.
How are you bearing up? Your health?
My health is excellent, thank you.
Oh, I only meant have you recovered from your journey?
I have indeed.
Good. And I noticed in the Sistine that you found someone to vote for?
Yes. I voted for you. Forgive me! Am I not supposed to say?
No, it’s not... I’m honoured, but...My dear Vincent - may I call you Vincent? - I’m not a serious candidate. My vocation lies in a different...
After the conclave, I hope to resign as Dean and to leave Rome altogether. So, you see, I...
Why? Lawrence is wrong-footed.
I have been experiencing some... difficulties...
With your faith?
Prayer. I...
“I cry out to You, God but You do not answer.”
I only mention it to illustrate my point that I am in no way worthy to be Pope.

Any man who is truly worthy must consider himself unworthy. Isn’t that the point you were making in your homily? That without doubt there can be no faith? It resonated with my own exper ience. In my ministry I have witnessed scenes which would make any man skeptical of God’s mercy.
You received a vote yourself didn’t you?
I did. It was absurd.
Then imagine how you would feel if I insisted on voting for you and by some miracle you won.
It would be a disaster for the Church.
That is how it would be if I became Pope. Think a bout what I’m asking.
Aldo, I feel wretched that my meagre tally may have come at your expense.
Your Eminence?
I’m sorry to disturb you. May I have a word?
Of course. One moment.
Excuse me, at this time of day I always try to meditate for an hour...
In my travels I became used to not always having electricity. Now I find it helpful when I pray alone.
I must see if it helps me.
Yes. Your difficulty with prayer.
If I may say... sometimes I find, instead of speaking, I have to become silent. And in the silence wait for God to be heard.
Yes. I’m sure you’re right.
Excuse me...
The other night you were kind enough to say yo u had voted for me. I don’t know if you’ve continued to do so, but if you have I would like to repeat my plea to you to stop.
Why?
First, because I lack the spiritual depth to be Pope. And secondly I can’t possibly win. A long drawn out Conclave would be seen by the media as proof that the Church is in crisis.
You have come to ask me to vote for Cardinal Tremblay?
Yes. A nd to urge your supporters to do the same.
Cardinal Tremblay has already spoken to me about this.
I’m sure he has.
You want me to vote for a man you see as ambitious?
I do not want to see Tedesco as Pope. He would take the Church back to an earlier era.
I’m sorry. I cannot vote for a man unless he is the one I deem most worthy to be Pope. And for me, that is not Cardinal Tremblay. It is you.
I don’t want your vote!
Never the less, you have it.
Did I do the right thing, Vincent?
No one who follows their conscience ever does wrong, Your Eminence.
Then we shall walk, Willi.

< O Father, so that we may guide and watch over Your Church, give to us, Your servants, the blessings of intelligence, truth and peace, so that we may strive to know Your will, and serve You with total dedication. For Christ our Lord... >

Ecclesiae tuae, Domine, rector et custos, infunde, quaesumus, famulis tuis spiritum intelligentiae, veritatis et pacis, ut, quae tibi placita sunt, toto corde cognoscant et agnita tota virtute sectentur. Per Christum Dominum nostrum. From the assembled Conclave comes the low rumble o f “Amen.”
< In the name of the whole College of Cardinals, I ask you, Cardinal Benitez, do you accept your canonical election as Supreme Pontiff?>
Acceptasne electionem de te canonice factam in Summum Pontificem?
< Do you accept? >
Acceptasne electionem de te canonice factam in Summum Pontificem?
< I accept. >
Accepto.
< And by what name do you wish to be called? >
Quo nomine vis vocari?
< Innocent. >
Innocentius.
Monsignor, I’m sorry to interrupt you...
Ray...? Startled, O’
I think you should start gathering the cardinal’s notes. The sooner we light the stoves, the sooner the world will know we have a new Pope.
Are you alright?
Of course.
You too, Father.
It seems that even the smallest vestments are too large... I was waiting for you to come.
You must tell me about this treatment at the clinic in Geneva.
Must I, Dean?
Yes, you must! Within the hour you will be the most famous man in the world! So tell me - what is your situation?
My “situatio n,” as you call it, is the same as when I was ordained a priest, the same as when I was made a cardinal.
But the... treatment... in Geneva...
There was no treatment. I considered it, prayed for guidance. And decided against it.
And what would it have been, this treatment?
It was called a laparoscopic hysterectomy.
You have to understand, when I was a child, there was no way of knowing my “situation” was more...

It was a very dark time for me. I felt as if my entire life as a priest had been lived in a state of sin. Of course, I offered my resignation to the Holy Father. I flew to Rome and told him everything.
He knew?
I would assume so. After all, he made me a cardinal in pectore in full knowledge of who I am.
We considered surgery to have what you might regard as the “female” parts of my body removed. But th e night before I was due to fly I realised I was mistaken.
Then you... you are still...?
I am what God made me. And perhaps it is my difference that will make me useful. I think again of your sermon. I know what it is to exist between the world’s certainties.
Who knows about this, apart from O’Ma lley?
Only yourself.
And one other of course.
God.
